Shriver Hall and reappear

its drive to renovate existing
Homewood buildings and construct new ones.

phase is the. beginning of

the completion of renovations

departments can't function as
well as they could. Our point is
to bring the buildings to
modern standards to give the

best standards possible for
research and teaching."

Shriver comes from a $209

secured
last

million is slated for the construction of new Homewood
buildings or the renovation of
existing ones.

modifications to Shriver include the replacement of the
steam line to the building and
the construction of a new tier of
steps in front of the building.
He commented,"That was absolutely necessary because the
old brick steps deteriorated to
a point where they needed
replacement."

by Mary Cinder
In what will be one of the
largest development projects in
the city's history, Hopkins
recently announced plans for
the construction of a $500
million biomedical research
center on the outskirts of
Baltimore on Eastern Boulevard.

Dome Corporation, a forprofit subsidiary of the University and The Johns Hopkins

the complex, which will be
known as the Bayview Research
Campus, is scheduled for
around the turn of the century.
Initial plans outline the construction of new buildings containing 3.4 million square feet
of space over the next decade,

with the possibility of expansion to five million square feet.

surrounding the Francis Scott
Key Medical Center may create
as many as 5000 new jobs, according to a representative of
the Baltimore Economic Development Corporation. Ultimately the new complex will include
office and manufacturing space
for private corporations, a
hotel, a conference center and
restaurants, as well as part of
The Johns Hopkins Health
System's acute and long term
care medical facilities.

unique environment research

Johns Hopkins research and
the National Institutes of

McComas in an article in the
September 21 Sun. The

the site of the National Institute
of Aging's Gerontology

Clinical Research Center as well

Peace Child. Director of
Special Events Sherry Gill calls
the play "a one-of-a-kind
presentation" because the tour
marks the first time in history
that Soviet and American
children have performed
together in the United States.
The play, based on The
Peace Book by Bernard Benson, was written by David
Woollcombe with music by
David Gordon. The cast includes twelve Soviet and twelve
American children, Soviet pop
rock band Stas Namin, and
Soviet folk singer Ludmilla
Sentsina.
A promotional brochure
describes the play as "a
thoughtful and dynamic
musical drama about American
and Soviet young people
becoming friends and shaping
the future together." Rosie
Woollcombe, the author's wife,

explains, "The purpose of the
play is to get the children to
think about peace. They must
realize there are other people in
the world and we've all got to
live together." She adds that
children are encouraged to perform the play in schools, churches, and youth organizations.
The Washington, D.C. performance will end the tour,
which includes dates in York,
Harrisburg, Rochester, Boston,
New York City, the United Nations, Minneapolis, Vancouver,
Seattle, San Francisco, Los
Angeles, and Santa Barbara, as
well as appearances in the
Soviet Union.
Rosie Woollcombe remarked
that the play was very well
received in the Soviet Union
because "audiences in the
Soviet Union and the United
States are pretty much the
same."
The Peace Child Foundation
of Fairfax, VA, is sponsoring
the current-tour as a celebration
of the International Year of
Peace. A fact sheet supplied by
the foundation describes the
production as "a demonstra-

tion of cooper'ion, friendship,
mutual trust, understanding
and appreciation between
peoples of the Soviet Union and
the United States."
The non-profit organizaton
was founded in the United
States in 1982 after the British
version of the musical was performed at the Kennedy Center.
"The foundation exists as an
educational program, designed
to teach people about the Soviet
Union or any other country
with a different philosophy,"
states Rosie Woollcombe.
The proceeds will assist in
paying for the tour and support
a schedule of US-Soviet youth
exchanges planned for the summer of 1987.

forty-six people, will leave from
an as yet undisclosed location
on the Homewood Campus at
6:30 p.m. and return to campus
after the performance. Tickets
may be obtained at the Office
of Special Events, located on
the first floor of Shriver Hall,
beteen 8:30 and 5. Admission
and transportation are included in the price of $32.50.

The New Alcohol Policy

Every year at about this time, the Inter Fraternity Council has a meeting with
Homewood administrators. And every
year, the I.F.C. shudders from the administration's fire-and-brimstone prophesies about enforcement of the ever
changing alcohol policy. This year has
been no exception.
Last week, Dean of Adminstration
Robert Welch, Dean of Students Chris
Colombo, and Director of Student Activities Mary Ellen Porter met with the
I.F.C. to announce yet another change,
in the enforcement of the University's'
alcohol policy.
According to the new policy, if any
fraternity is caught serving alcohol to a
minor. all frats will be forced to go dry.
However, if an offending fraternity is
first turned in by members of another
brotherhood, only the offending frat will
be punished.
The threats of punishment for alcohol
violations come as no surprise, but the
silliness of pitting frat against frat in enforcing the policy is something novel.
Welch, Colombo, and Porter argue
that fraternities need to work together in
obeying the law and that the new policy
will enhance a cooperative spirit
throughout the Greek system. Such
hopes seem naive at best.
The more likely result of the new enforcement measures will be to promote
tattle-telling and encourage interfraternity rivalries which until now have
have been relatively subdued.
The the new measures for the enforcement of the University's alcohol policy
point to a problem of growing concern.
During the last three or four years since
the state changed its drinking age from
19 to 21, the University has taken upon

itself the obligation of actively enforcing Maryland State drinking laws
through every means it has at its
disposal. Fraternities have been fined,
placed on social probation, threatened
with the loss of pledge classes, etc....
Now the University seems ready to
recruit a network of spies to infiltrate
parties. The University has gone too far.
As an institution of higher learning,
the University is charged with the responsibility of complying with state laws.
That means, for example, that the
University should strictly monitor drinking at the functions and events it sponsors. The University drinking policies at
on-campus events, therefore, are quite
reasonable.
The University, however, is not
obligated to enforce state laws at the
private off-campus gatherings of its
students. Law enforcement is best left in
the hands of recognized law enforcement
agencies, particularly when offending
groups are only tangentally associated
with the University at best.
During the last three or four years, the
University's alcohol policy has had
relatively little effect on the drinking
habits of most students. Like almost any
other group of socially adjusted adults,
students can and will find a way to drink.
Fortunately, the availabilty of alcohol
in the local area has not yet forced
students to make dangerous drives to
waterholes farther away, at least not in
large numbers. By watering down the
new enforcement measures of the alcohol
policy to simple compliance with state
law rather than active enforcement, the
University will provide a much greater
service to its students and the state.

Planning for Intersession
School has only just started again, so
it's difficult to start thinking about the
holidays. This year, however, students
and faculty need to begin planning for
the Yuletide Season early.
During the last several years, Intersession, the three week period of informal
and relaxed classes at the beginning of
January, has been fighting a losing battle. Originally, the program was intended to provide students and faculty a
chance to interact closely in learning
situations not usually available at
Hopkins.
The goal was to give students a nopressure opportunity to explore topics

time, some opportunities were created

their departments.

balance between "exploratory courses"
and advanced departmental work has
slipped percipitiously in favor of the latter. Today, Intersession suffers from a
plethora of upper-level seminars of extremely limited interest and a drastic
shortage of the inter-departmental mind
expanding courses for which the pro-- -

It's time now to ensure that Intersession '87 doesn't follow the route of its

Making Intersession come off well this
year will require a coordinated and
cooperative effort between students and
administrators—an effort that needs to
begin immediately. Students should
begin pestering departments and specific
professors to offer lntersession courses
they would like to take now. The adminstration needs to begin serious work

faculty members to offer Intersession
courses.(Traditionally, faculty members
have not been paid for their Intersession
teaching.)

Undergraduate Studies issued a comprehensive report on the status of Intersession and proposed a number of
well-grounded ideas for improving the
program. We'll have more to say about
some of those ideas in upcoming weeks.
For now, it's time to dust off the report
and begin serious consideration of what
classes and what incentives will make Intersession '87 the best yet.

To the Editor:
I am deeply troubled by
statements made in the editorial
entitled "Disciplining D.U.".
The term "accomplices in terrorism" used to describe the
D.U. members at the house on
the night of the incident reeks
of sensationalism. It was made
quite clear during the trial that
there was no political intent or
intent to murder behind the
firebombing. This was confirmed by the judge in his verdict.
How can an act with no ulterior
motive be considered terrorism? I find an analogy com-

paring D.U. brothers to Muammar Khadafi very offensive.
Another problem with the article is the assumption of
substantial fraternity involvement. Mike Moffa did not
undertake his actions as "the
elected president of a fraternity," but as Mike Moffa. The
principle applies to the other
two defendants.
While it is true that the plan
originated in the house, and
there was a reconnaissance mission, it is important to
remember that nobody realized
that the bombing would actually take place. Their colleagues
had no idea that the
perpetrators would carry out

their task. Why go through all
the preparations if nothing
would result? Stranger things
have happened when fraternity
brothers start drinking.
The judge made quite clear
that while this act was a crime,
the participants did not appreciate the consequences of
their actions. If the defendants
were blind to the results of their
actions, is it fair to demand that
their associates be aware of the
ramifications? If you still
believe that the fraternity
should be held accountable for
the actions of three members,
I suggest that you reread the
judge's decision.

Watering Down
Lift of Shanty-Ban
The New Alcohol Policy

Every year at about this time, the Inter Fraternity Council has a meeting with
Homewood administrators. And every
year, the I.F.C. shudders from the administration's fire-and-brimstone prophesies about enforcement of the ever
changing alcohol policy. This year has
been no exception.
Last week, Dean of Adminstration
Robert Welch, Dean of Students Chris
Colombo, and Director of Student Activities Mary Ellen Porter met with the
I.F.C. to announce yet another change,
in the enforcement of the University's'
alcohol policy.
According to the new policy, if any
fraternity is caught serving alcohol to a
minor. all frats will be forced to go dry.
However, if an offending fraternity is
first turned in by members of another
brotherhood, only the offending frat will
be punished.
The threats of punishment for alcohol
violations come as no surprise, but the
silliness of pitting frat against frat in enforcing the policy is something novel.
Welch, Colombo, and Porter argue
that fraternities need to work together in
obeying the law and that the new policy
will enhance a cooperative spirit
throughout the Greek system. Such
hopes seem naive at best.
The more likely result of the new enforcement measures will be to promote
tattle-telling and encourage interfraternity rivalries which until now have
have been relatively subdued.
The the new measures for the enforcement of the University's alcohol policy
point to a problem of growing concern.
During the last three or four years since
the state changed its drinking age from
19 to 21, the University has taken upon

itself the obligation of actively enforcing Maryland State drinking laws
through every means it has at its
disposal. Fraternities have been fined,
placed on social probation, threatened
with the loss of pledge classes, etc....
Now the University seems ready to
recruit a network of spies to infiltrate
parties. The University has gone too far.
As an institution of higher learning,
the University is charged with the responsibility of complying with state laws.
That means, for example, that the
University should strictly monitor drinking at the functions and events it sponsors. The University drinking policies at
on-campus events, therefore, are quite
reasonable.
The University, however, is not
obligated to enforce state laws at the
private off-campus gatherings of its
students. Law enforcement is best left in
the hands of recognized law enforcement
agencies, particularly when offending
groups are only tangentally associated
with the University at best.
During the last three or four years, the
University's alcohol policy has had
relatively little effect on the drinking
habits of most students. Like almost any
other group of socially adjusted adults,
students can and will find a way to drink.
Fortunately, the availabilty of alcohol
in the local area has not yet forced
students to make dangerous drives to
waterholes farther away, at least not in
large numbers. By watering down the
new enforcement measures of the alcohol
policy to simple compliance with state
law rather than active enforcement, the
University will provide a much greater
service to its students and the state.

Planning for Intersession
School has only just started again, so
it's difficult to start thinking about the
holidays. This year, however, students
and faculty need to begin planning for
the Yuletide Season early.
During the last several years, Intersession, the three week period of informal
and relaxed classes at the beginning of
January, has been fighting a losing battle. Originally, the program was intended to provide students and faculty a
chance to interact closely in learning
situations not usually available at
Hopkins.
The goal was to give students a nopressure opportunity to explore topics
outside their own disciplines. At the same
time, some opportunities were created
for students to do advanced work within
their departments.
Unfortunately, in recent years, the
balance between "exploratory courses"
and advanced departmental work has
slipped percipitiously in favor of the latter. Today, Intersession suffers from a
plethora of upper-level seminars of extremely limited interest and a drastic
shortage of the inter-departmental mind
expanding courses for which the pro-- -

gram was initiated.
It's time now to ensure that Intersession '87 doesn't follow the route of its
recent predecessors.
Making Intersession come off well this
year will require a coordinated and
cooperative effort between students and
administrators—an effort that needs to
begin immediately. Students should
begin pestering departments and specific
professors to offer lntersession courses
they would like to take now. The adminstration needs to begin serious work
on developping greater incentives for
faculty members to offer Intersession
courses.(Traditionally, faculty members
have not been paid for their Intersession
teaching.)
Last year, the Committee on
Undergraduate Studies issued a comprehensive report on the status of Intersession and proposed a number of
well-grounded ideas for improving the
program. We'll have more to say about
some of those ideas in upcoming weeks.
For now, it's time to dust off the report
and begin serious consideration of what
classes and what incentives will make Intersession '87 the best yet.

To the Editor:
I am deeply troubled by
statements made in the editorial
entitled "Disciplining D.U.".
The term "accomplices in terrorism" used to describe the
D.U. members at the house on
the night of the incident reeks
of sensationalism. It was made
quite clear during the trial that
there was no political intent or
intent to murder behind the
firebombing. This was confirmed by the judge in his verdict.
How can an act with no ulterior
motive be considered terrorism? I find an analogy com-

paring D.U. brothers to Muammar Khadafi very offensive.
Another problem with the article is the assumption of
substantial fraternity involvement. Mike Moffa did not
undertake his actions as "the
elected president of a fraternity," but as Mike Moffa. The
principle applies to the other
two defendants.
While it is true that the plan
originated in the house, and
there was a reconnaissance mission, it is important to
remember that nobody realized
that the bombing would actually take place. Their colleagues
had no idea that the
perpetrators would carry out

their task. Why go through all
the preparations if nothing
would result? Stranger things
have happened when fraternity
brothers start drinking.
The judge made quite clear
that while this act was a crime,
the participants did not appreciate the consequences of
their actions. If the defendants
were blind to the results of their
actions, is it fair to demand that
their associates be aware of the
ramifications? If you still
believe that the fraternity
should be held accountable for
the actions of three members,
I suggest that you reread the
judge's decision.

game below.

strategy, hand-eye coordination

eventualy get tired of the
repititious nature of the game.

human brain—sometimes 10 or
20 of them—spontaneously
controlling the way the game
unfolds and thus an essentially
infinite variety of twists and
turns are introduced," he
concluded.

North Point Boulevard off of
exit 40 on the 695 Beltway, is
only the eighth Photon in the
United States, beating out such
cities as New York, Chicago

opened in Dallas in 1984,

over 400,000, and 130 franchises are already planned
